contents:
Three writers have submitted text to go with the illustration.

Writer A

Plunder and destructive, non-systematic excavations were hallmarks of Egyptian archaeology and pyramid exploration in the 19th century. Italian Bernardino Drovetti, who first arrived in Egypt with Napolean, amassed an enormously valuable collection by looting precious Egyptian artifacts and selling to the highest bidder.


Writer B

Bernardino Drovetti served as the French Consul-General in Egypt between 1802 and 1814. Drovetti financed Egyptian excavations that enhanced the world’s understanding of Ancient Egypt and provided the world with precious archeological treasures that formed the foundation of the Egyptian Museum in Turin.


Writer C

Italian-born diplomat Bernardino Drovetti’s excavations in Egypt in the early 1800s unearthed valuable artifacts and papyruses that enhance our knowledge of Egypt. However, excavations of the time, including Drovetti’s, were often destructive, more akin to a treasure hunt than an archaeological endeavor.
